column7: Suncorp Group Limited is a publicly-listed company limited by shares and incorporated in Australia. Suncorp Group Limited shares are listed on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX).

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: On 4 August 2023, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) announced it would deny authorisation of the planned sale. As part of the merger authorisation process, ANZ has indicated it will refer the ACCCÃ¢ÂÂs decision to the Australian Competition Tribunal (the Tribunal) for review. Suncorp will support ANZ during the process. In addition to the TribunalÃ¢ÂÂs approval, the sale remains subject to the amendment of the State Financial Institutions and Metway Merger Act 1996 (Qld) and permission from the Federal Treasurer under the Financial Sector (Shareholdings) Act 1998. Subject to all approvals being received, the Group expects the sale to be completed by the middle of the 2024 calendar year. The estimated cash consideration for the sale of $4,900 million is subject to standard completion adjustments.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: Our FY23 Annual Report includes information on our financial and non-financial performance for the reporting period 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023.

Responding to climate change and the opportunities emerging from the net-zero transition are central to SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs purpose as an insurer and bank to millions of households and businesses across Australia and New Zealand.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Insurance (Australia) provides consumer, commercial and personal injury insurance products to the Australian market. Suncorp Group is one of AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs largest general insurers by Gross Written Premium (GWP) and the countryÃ¢ÂÂs largest compulsory third-party insurer. Suncorp Bank Focuses on lending, deposit gathering and transaction account services to personal, Small and Medium Enterprise (SME), commercial and agribusiness customers. Suncorp New Zealand Delivers financial services to New Zealanders through SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs go-to-market general and life insurance brands. Made up of Vero Insurance, Asteron Life and AA Insurance, AA Money and AA Life joint ventures with the New Zealand Automobile Association (NZAA).
Total full-time equivalent (FTE) employees are 13,377, and total headcount is 13,624.
The maximum-term contractor headcount is 721, and the employees covered by collective bargaining agreements are 99.6% in FY23.

SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs Corporate Governance Statement (Statement) outlines our approach to corporate governance and principal governance practices. The Board believes high standards of corporate governance are essential to achieving Suncorp's business objectives, which are aimed at creating value and sustainable outcomes for Suncorp shareholders, customers and the communities in which Suncorp operates.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: Meetings shall be held at a frequency determined by the Nomination Committee. Special meetings may be convened by the Nomination Committee Chairman as required. Non-executive Directors of the Board who are not Nomination Committee members may attend meetings of the Nomination Committee as observers and receive copies of papers. Executive Directors may attend Nomination Committee meetings and participate in discussions on matters considered by the Nomination Committee at the invitation of the Nomination Committee Chairman. A meeting quorum will have two members or any other number the Board determines. The agenda and supporting documentation shall be circulated to the Nomination Committee members at a reasonable period before each meeting. The secretary of the Nomination Committee shall be the Company Secretary or another person nominated by the Board. The secretary of the Nomination Committee shall circulate minutes to members of the Nomination Committee and the Board as soon as practicable after each meeting.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Christine McLoughlin, AM, has been a director of the Suncorp Group since 2015 and Chairman since September 2018. She is Chairman of the Nomination Committee and an ex-officio member of the Audit, Customer, People and Remuneration, and Risk Committees.

The Board believes high standards of corporate governance are essential to achieving Suncorp's business objectives, which are aimed at creating value and sustainable outcomes for Suncorp shareholders, customers and the communities in which Suncorp operates.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: Continued focus on Board education and development, including through Ã¢ÂÂ¢ site visits and immersion sessions to gain valuable first-hand insights about SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs businesses, people and critical trends impacting Suncorp (including ESG, technology and cyber security) Ã¢ÂÂ¢ participation in crucial stakeholder engagement forums, including our Customer Advocate Day Ã¢ÂÂ¢ discussions with external advisers where relevant and necessary

The Constitution, Board Charter and Suncorp Code of Conduct highlight the importance placed on ensuring the management of actual, potential or perceived conflicts of interest. Each director has a continuing obligation to keep the Board advised of any interest that has arisen that could potentially conflict with those of the Suncorp Group. Where a director has an actual, potential or perceived conflict in a matter being considered by the Board, the director will: ÃÂ declare that conflict of interest ÃÂ not receive the relevant Board papers ÃÂ not be present when the matter is considered during a Board or Committee meeting and ÃÂ not participate in any decision on the case, unless the Board Chairman (or if the relevant director is the Board Chairman, either of the Board Audit or Risk Committee Chairmen) determines otherwise.

New non-executive directors meet with the Board Chairman, the Group CEO, members of the ELT, other relevant senior managers (including the Suncorp Group Customer Advocate) and the external auditor to learn about SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs structure, business activities, strategic priorities and critical risks. Ongoing director education is provided through regular management presentations on key business activities and topical issues for Suncorp, including areas subject to regulatory or operational change. Directors also engage with and receive presentations from ÃÂ employees below ELT level to deepen their understanding of SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs operations and culture ÃÂ external experts, where relevant and required. Directors are expected to supplement their knowledge beyond that facilitated by Suncorp on topical issues of broader significance.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The Board skills matrix sets out the essential skills, expertise and qualities that the Board believes are necessary for the effective governance of Suncorp. During FY23, the Board reviewed and updated the matrix categories to ensure they continue to reflect the nature of SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs current strategic priorities and operating environment. ÃÂÃÂÃÂ gave preliminary consideration to the optimal Board governance structure for Suncorp as a dedicated insurance company (which remains subject to the completion of the sale of Suncorp Bank), including the skills and experience that would be necessary in the future. Each director undertakes an annual self-assessment against the skills matrix categories, aggregated and peer-reviewed by the Board. Where a director has been rated as having a developed level of capability in a given classification (being a level that can confidently be drawn upon to add to the BoardÃ¢ÂÂs deliberations), it is reflected in the Board skills matrix. SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs 2023 Board skills matrix (as shown on the following page) demonstrates the alignment between the BoardÃ¢ÂÂs currently desired and actual range of skills and expertise.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: The Board undertakes an annual evaluation of its performance and the performance of its committees and each director individually, including the Chairman. The Board and Committee Chairmen facilitate group discussions, generally supported by a questionnaire process, and the Chairman meets individually with each director. The Board then discusses and considers the evaluation outcomes and agrees on any necessary recommendations. The most recent performance evaluation was completed in July-August 2022, and an assessment is underway during August 2023. In addition, the Board periodically assists an external consultant to facilitate the evaluation process. The Board is considering the optimum time to do so about completing the Bank sale (subject to regulatory approvals). The above-structured evaluation processes supplement an ongoing focus at Board and Committee meetings on continuous improvement opportunities, including work plans, agendas and materials to support practical meeting discussions between Directors and management.

The Group Scorecard is intentionally weighted to incentivise executives to focus on financial and non-financial measures, ensuring compliance with APRAÃ¢ÂÂs Remuneration Prudential Standard CPS 511. Further details on the steps in the Group Scorecard are outlined on the page.

The People and Remuneration Committee endorses the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs people and remuneration frameworks and practices to the Board for approval. It assists the Board in fulfilling its responsibilities by ensuring frameworks are in place that enable the Group to attract, motivate and retain talent and support the achievement of SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs strategic objectives and cultural aspirations. Remuneration arrangements and outcomes for the Group CEO are recommended by the Chairman of the Board, endorsed by the People and Remuneration Committee, and approved by the Board. For Senior Executives, these are guided by the Group CEO, supported by the People and Remuneration Committee, and approved by the Board.

The focus at Suncorp on delivering our strategic plan underpinned another strong year for the Group despite the backdrop of continued global economic and political volatility. I am proud of the resilience of our company and what our employees have delivered for our customers, communities, and shareholders in FY23.
